name: Nature's Strongest Defenders - A Guide to Druids
author: Maximillian Kane

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hail, ECBers. Turns out today I'm at the office, stuck answering phones as my secretary won't be making it to work. Ah.. those hangover Mondays! Well, I'll not let that opportunity slide, I'll spend this time producing yet another guide to one of my favourite classes: Druids.

As the "intro" to this guide, let me tell you a bit about the strengths and weaknesses of the class:

- Strengths:

1- The MOST AMAZING STRENGTH or trait of the Druid class is that you can pump your casting stat (Wisdom), grab Zen Archery and be proficient in all areas of combat: Casting, Ranged combat and Melee combat. That happens because Druids use shifting to fight in melee, and all of their shapes override the character's Strength, Dexterity AND Constitution scores (I'm not talking about shifter shapes here, just Druid shapes), replacing them with the ones from the copied creature. This means you can have VERY LOW SCORES in all three of those stats without hurting your melee prowess, so your spells will have very high DCs thanks to the high Wisdom (which can be capped by Owl's Insight alone), and that will also make your ranged AB high and your melee AB will also be at the very least acceptable due to the high STR of your shapes (or DEX if you have Weapon Finesse, although you don't have many ways of buffing DEX as well as you can buff STR).

2- Animal Companions are simply the most reliable summons you can find, and it takes a long time for them to become obsolete. The Druid has incredibly good buffs to make their companions very strong additions to their combat strategy. A high AC Druid can tank and let the companion kill pretty much anything in the way.

3- Druid spells are also very good, and with the number 1 Strength I mentioned, any non-shifter Druid should have high DCs on their spells. Their buffs are also very useful, although with a limited scope. They have very interesting offensive spells in many forms, but my favourite are the disabling ones. I'll talk more in-depth about this later when I discuss spells.

4- Many skill points per level, although not such a great selection of skills (but they can be saved up and spent on taking a level of another class ).

- Weaknesses:

1- No direct AB buffs. Even though I did say that Druids have a very acceptable AB throughout, it comes mostly from the high STR of their shapes. Druids can only buff Strength (very well, though), not AB, so around level 30 and then again closing to 40, the AB becomes less attractive, at level 30 because you don't have Dragon Shape yet and Elemental Shapes AB is really really bad at that stage, and approaching 40 because you can reach an AB in the mid-50s even in Dragon Shape, which isn't bad but isn't exactly top notch either. The fact that WF and EWF Unarmed don't work while shifted, which is essentially a bug, would help with that, so screw Bioware for not fixing this! BTW, just in case you're wondering, they DON'T WORK, I know your character sheet is showing them, but the character sheet LIES! Improved Critical (Unarmed), Epic Prowess and Overwhelming Critical (Unarmed) work.

2- Healing is somewhat difficult to manage in melee, because you need to de-shift to cast any healing spell. Potions work while shifted, which is great if your server has them in abundance. Also, re-buffing can be a problem if you get dispelled for the same reason. The thing is that all creatures you transform into have much higher CON scores than you, so when you de-shift, the decrease in CON makes you come back with 1 HP most of the time when you're badly wounded while shifted. You don't die from this, but if any CON buffs expire just after you de-shift or you get hit before you manage to heal, then you die.

3- Can't buff stats except STR and WIS (with a bit of CON and DEX on the side thanks to AoV and Blood Frenzy, but those don't last long) The only 2 stat buffs that are long-lasting are Bull's Strength and Owl's Insight. This somewhat limits the usefulness of DEX shapes, like the Air Elemental. If you could buff DEX like you can Strength, Weapon Finesse and Air Elemental Shape would be much more effective and attractive.

4- Not all gear merges while shifted, which means that sometimes you THINK you have death immunity from a belt, then shift and find yourself dying from an instant death spell. Or another thing that's a pain in the ass is that sometimes if you have a pendant of Wisdom, for example, then you cast Owl's Insight and shift, if you get dispelled while shifted, you'll lose some of your memorized spells as the amulet doesn't merge with your shape. I'll talk about this more thoroughly later on when I talk about the shapes.

All in all, the Druid class has many tools to make very powerful characters overall.

HOW TO USE DRUID IN A BUILD:

I will state here that Druids can be used in three ways:

1- Just to attain the requirements for the Shifter class:

You need 5 levels of Druid to become a shifter. If your intention is to go heavy on shifter, then you won't be using the Druid side of the build much, so aside from a few buffs, you'll just be a shifter. This doesnt mean that all shifter builds have to go low on Druid. In fact the most common spread for this class combo is Druid 22 Shifter 17 Monk 1. Consider Druid 22 as part of the 3rd group of builds.

2- Just to get Dragon Shape:

This type of build was WAY MORE COMMON in the pre-1.69 patches. In the last patch, Dragon Shape came to need at least 18 levels of Druid, which ruined many of those builds, and worsened many others. In this type of build, Druid is a secondary class, the buffs are easily dispellable, but, as usual, the spell DCs are high and the focus of taking Druid is for Dragon Shape, but the combinations are somewhat limited because of the heavy Wisdom requirement and the increased levels needed. A Dragon with Epic Dodge is no longer possible without severely gimping its power, as the stat requirements are unattainable without dropping Monk. You'll need to take CoT levels for Great Wisdom feats and Rogue or SD levels for the other ED requirements. The loss of Monk AC and Attack Progression alone makes me think it's not worth it. You can still have a Dragon with all the arcane spells, but the AB would suffer some more and EW would only be taken at 39, but what would hurt the build most is that you'd only be able to take the cheesy Monk lvl at 40. So if you want a Dragon with Epic Warding, Druid 20 Bard 4 PM 16 is the way to go (no high-level arcane spells here).

3- Druid as the main class:

This is the most recommended usage for the class. The buffs will be nearly if not completely undispellable, the spell DCs will be very high, which should be enhanced even further by Spell Focus feats. The animal companion will also be quite powerful for most of your leveling, and with a summoned creature to aid it and a few disabling spells (my favourites), it will wreak havoc with the regular mobs. In the early stages you can also use Animal Empathy to have an extra summoned creature, just in case 2 aren't enough ^^. I used to play on a server where you could charm Magical Beasts with high scores of Animal Empathy, so I had my pet Manticore walking around by my side killing everything on sight. The downside is that I'd have to kill it before resting or just drop her off somewhere far away enough from me so that I could rest, then rest and get her back. If you foget to do that, It's probably Dirtnap express for you, as you'll lose all your buffs, rest and then you'll stop dominating it, it'll turn hostile and attack, breaking your rest and probably killing you. The same goes for all Hostile animals charmed with Animal Empathy. I wish I could say this never happened to me, but it has, more often than I care to admit. It's so pathetic, I know, it's almost like I shouldn't be writing this guide, but reading one .

Anyway, now we'll begin to understand this great class. We'll talk about the spells, then animal companions and then the shapes, and at the end I'll give a few pointers on how to play a Druid.

THE DRUID SPELLBOOK:

Druids have MANY useless spells in their spellbook, especially in the lower levels, but as you advance in levels, you'll get much better ones. I'll go first into the main buffs and then offensive spells.

- BUFFS:

1- Long-term: Endure Elements (1), Barkskin (2), Bull's Strength(2), Ultravision (2), Protection from Elements(3), Stoneskin (4), Freedom of Movement (4), Death Ward(5), Owl's Insight (5), Spell Resitance (5), True Seeing (6), Greater Stoneskin(6), Premonition(8).

- Endure Elements: Not a bad spell to have, especially early on, mainly because it lasts 24 hours regardless of level. Same goes for Protection from Elements.

- Barkskin: The Druid signature buff, although it can be attained by Clerics with the Plant Domain. It gives +3 Natural AC till level 7, then +4 till lvl 12 and +5 from 13 on. If you play on a mid-magic setting, this means that the progression of this spell is better than Cleric buffs and any items that you may acquire at that stage, so it's a very good spell.

- Bull's Strength: Good spell to boost carrying capacity and AB and damage for both you and your companion. The effect carries over to the shifted shapes.

- Ultravision: Good spell to protect you against the effects of Darkness, but you still can't see anything in there.

- Stoneskin: Good DR (10/+5) spell for the companion and summoned creature EARLY ON, and for you before you get Greater Stoneskin and Premonition. Later on it's less useful.

- Death Ward: Makes the target immune to Death spells and effects, for you and your companion.

- Owl's Insight: This spell is one of the reasons I say Druid-heavy is absolutely recommended. It gives +1 to Wisdom for every 2 levels of Druid and caps wisdom ALONE at 24 levels of Druid. It's one of the best spells in the game. The effect of this spell carries over to the shifted shapes, so if you have at least 1 level of Monk, you'll have up to +6 AC while shifted thanks to this great spell.

- Spell Resistance: Gives 12 +1 every caster level to Spell Resistance. It's really good and doesn't cap, so the more levels in Druid, the higher your SR will be.

- True Seeing: This spell gives sight of hidden and invisible creatures. It's especially useful for Druids, because their bonus AC in shapes is Dodge, so your AC will be significantly lower if you're caught flat-footed.

- Greater Stoneskin: Better DR than Stoneskin (20/+5), but only works on yourself not on others.

- Premonition: The best DR spell that you'll have access to. Gives 30/+5 DR for an hour per level. It's also a personal spell.

2- Short-term: Blood Frenzy (2), Aura of Vitality (7).

- Blood Frenzy: A mini-Barbarain Rage, this spell gives +2 to STR and CON, lowering AC by 1. Good spell to help cap Strength. All properties, including the AC penalty, transfer to the shifted shapes.

- Aura of Vitality: This is a VERY GOOD SPELL, exclusive to Druids and Clerics with the War Domain. It gives 4 to STR, DEX and CON.

As far as buffs, these are your bread and butter. I have never played hiding and sneaking Druids, so One With the Land, Camouflage and Mass Camouflage were less useful to me, but you could use them to increase your stealth with the right build. There are also buffs for your companion that are definitely worth mentioning: Magic Fang (1), Greater Magic Fang (3) and Awaken (5).

- Magic Fang: Gives +1 to AB and damage to your companion. Nothing special, but OK till you get GMF.

- Greater Magic fang: +1 per 3 caster levels to AB and damage of your companion, this is nature's version of the Divine Favor spell applied to your companion. The weird thing about it is that if you (like me) buff from the radial menu, this spell can only be cast on yourself, even though it only affects the companion.

- Awaken: Raises Strength and Constitution of the companion by 4, AB by 2 and Wisdom by 1d10 (good only for Will saves). The best thing is that this spell is PERMANENT. It lasts for as long as you have the companion by your side, even after rests. Better fir Single Player modules, because they save your character differently from servers. In online servers, everytime you log out, your companion gets unsummoned and you'll lose all the buffs you cast on him.

- OFFENSIVE SPELLS:

For the sake of organization, I will divide these offensive spells into 3 types: Disabling Spells, Damage spells and Instant Death spells. There aren't that many useful ones, really, but this way you can organize your head better too .

1- Disabling Spells: Entangle (1), Grease (1), Vine Mine (5), Stonehold (6), Nature's Balance (8), Storm of Vengeance (9).

- Entangle: Holds the target still if it fails a save, but the target can still attack and cast spells at will. Negated by Freedom.

- Grease: Slows any non-Druid target that walks over it, and if the target fails a reflex save, it also gets knocked down. Freedom and Immunity to knockdown negate each of the effects respectively. There is also a specific immunity to Grease, which negates both effects simultaneously.

- Vine Mine: When you cast it, you have to choose one of 3 effects, the only one I've ever used is Entangle.

- Stonehold: I just LOVE this spell! It paralyzes all targets in the area if they fail a save. The best thing about this spell is that targets need to make a WILL save. This spell, along with SoV, is the reason why I like the Conjuration school so much.

- Nature's Balance: Reduces target creature's SR, helping your spells penetrate Spell Resistance.

- Storm of Vengeance: If you read my Cleric guide, it's THE ULTIMATE STUNNER! Now not all Clerics have high Wisdom and I already said that, can you imagine what it's like with a VERY HIGH DC? Yes, AWESOME! You'll pretty much stun anything that's not immune to it or focused on saves. With this spell, you needn't fear being surrounded, you'll actually welcome it!

2- Damage Spells: Flame Lash (2), Call Lightning (3), Flame Strike (4), Ice Storm (5), Inferno (5), Creeping Doom (7), Fire Storm (7), Harm (7), Sunburst (8).

- Flame Lash: Worthless little Fire Damage spell. Only good to finish off Harmed opponents.

- Call Lightning: This spell does VERY GOOD damage on a very large AoE, but only works outdoors.

- Flame Strike: Does Fire and Divine damage to enemies in a small to average AoE.

- Ice Storm: This spell is great as it has no save nor is it subject to Spell Resistance, does Cold and Physical damage.

- Inferno: This spell is good if you like killing a monster in 1 year, rather than a few rounds. It has no save, which is great, but does 2d6 fire damage a round for 1 round per level. I'll be honest with ya, IMO Ice Storm or Empowered Call Lightning are much better to have at level 5 than this one. You can use it extended at level 6 for double damage (takes twice as long).

- Creeping Doom: Good no-save spell that does more damage each round a creature is in the area of effect and also slows enemies. However, there is a bug with it that makes prone creatures get up and move out of the AoE, so it's less useful.

- Fire Storm: Huge AoE spell cast around you that does Divine and Fire damage. Druids are THE ONLY CLASS that can cast Empowered Fire Storm, as it's a lvl 7 spell for them.

- Harm: Great spell to kill high HP monsters nearly instantly. Many servers have nerfed it. Fully heals undead.

- Sunburst: Good undead-damaging spell, pretty worthless against anything else.

3- Instant Death Spells: Slay Living (5), Drown (6), Finger of Death (8).

- Slay Living: Kills a single target if it fails a Fortitude save. Does 3d6 +1 per caster level Negative Energy damage if the target succeeds the save.

- Drown: Living creatures take 90% of their current hitpoints in damage, leaving them near-dead. This spell is here because the damage is only applied if the target fails a save, so it works similarly to the instant death spells. The best thing is that this spell isn't subject to immunities, except for the fact that it only works on livin creatures, so Undead and Constructs are immune to it.

- Finger of Death: Works the same as Slay Living, but has a higher DC because it's a higher level spell.

So basically there are 4 main schools in which you can have spell focus feats. My favourite is Conjuration, because not only it has the best spells (Grease, Stonehold and SoV), but Stonehold is a Will save spell, while SoV and Grease are Reflex, which allows you to attack the enemies weakest save most of the time. But Conjuration is also the school that's most affected by immunities, so if where you play they are abundant, you can choose another school, between Transmutation (for Drown DC), Necromancy (for Finger of Death and Slay Living) or my second favourite: Evocation for those juicy damage spells like Fire Storm. There are many REALLY GOOD damage spells from level 3 on, and you can always have a metamagic version of any of those in all levels from 3-9. They're all subject to Evasion (except for Ice Storm) and do half damage if a save is made, so a higher DC is very interesting to have. Not as interesting as a huge AoE damage and paralysis one, but interesting nevertheless.

DRUID ANIMAL COMPANIONS:

1- Brown Bear: This is the highest AB of all your companions, however, his AC is also the lowest. In vanilla NWN, that doesn't matter because the companion's AC is always gonna be low from a certain point on, so it's best to use them just to deal damage, and leave the tanking to either yourself or another summoned creature. The bear gains +1 STR for every level up to 20, so the AB will be very good if compared to the other companions.

2- Dire Wolf: This is tied in second place as the best companion to have. The great thing about this companion is that it gets +1 to DEX increases every level up to 20, ending up with a much more acceptable AC than any other companion. They're a good choice if you have CEP enhancements that can further their DEX and equip them with cloth armor and AC items. Their AB isn't good, but in the higher levels, nor will the Bear's AB be, unless you go with a near-pure Druid build.

3- Panther: This animal companion has the highest damage output of them all, thanks to the 10d6 Sneak Attack damage that they get from level 1-20 as a Rogue 1 level higher than the Panther (A lvl 6 Panther will have the same Sneak Attack dice and Uncanny Dodge bonuses as a lvl 7 Rogue). After lvl 20, the increase in Sneak Attack stops, but Uncanny Dodge continues to grow with levels.

I have never played anything else in terms of animal companions. The other ones might be useful or have a useful feature, but I wouldn't know. Generally, I use the Dire Wolf in the very early levels, because the AC is good and it can tank when you still don't have buffs or melee prowess. Your physical stats are just pathetic, so after level 5 or 6, I switch up to Brown Bear, cuz I already have Barkskin and Wildshape, then at level 26 Druid I switch back to the Wolf (only if there is the CEP option to equip them). I only use the Panther on my Sneaky builds, like my Bane Crusher halfling Ranger / Rogue / SD. A companion that's proficient in hiding and does lots of Sneak Attack damage can be a nice addition to a sneaky guy.

DRUID SHAPES:

First and foremost, I will tell you that all Druid shapes follow the same rules: not all items merge on shifts. I will explain how it works, so that you can equip yourself properly. All "armor" items merge on shifts, which basically means Armor, Shield and Helm. Only the highest AC modifier among those items will be added to your AC in the shifted shape. That's easy enough, but what's really cool is that all properties of those items also merge when you shift. So if you, for instance, have an armor that gives you Haste, then you become Hasted when you shift. If your Armor has a +5 AC modifier, then that one will be added to your shifted AC. This means you can equip a shield that gives you, for example, +3 Strength and no AC. That will effectively increase your STR without diminishing your AC. I say diminishing because normally, Druids have at least 1 level of Monk, for Wisdom AC and Unarmed progression (too much to pass up). You lose those when you equip armor or shields, but when you shift, the shield merges and disappears for as long as you remain shifted. Then you get the properties from the shield but without the penalty. The risk of doing this is that if you de-shift to heal, for example, and get attacked, your AC will be very low because the shield will be equipped and you won't have Wisdom AC and you will very likely die, so use with caution.

- WILDSHAPE:

Allows you to transform into an animal of your choice between Brown Bear, Panther, Wolf, Boar and Badger. At level 12, these shapes receive an upgrade to Dire Bear, Improved Panther, Dire Wolf, Dire Boar and Dire Badger. To be honest, I'm not exactly an expert in these forms, as I have used ONLY THE BEAR. The thing is that the Bear has the highest AB because it has the highest Strength, and the difference in AC isn't as significant to justify going for anything else. So just in case you're wondering about these shapes, let me provide you with the link, so feel free to try out any other shape if you want to challenge yourself or for whatever reason, but IMO bear is the only one that's worth something.

http://nwn.wikia.com/wiki/Wildshape

- ELEMENTAL SHAPE:

Allows you to transform into an elemental of your choice. Each type has a bonus special ability, except for the Earth elemental. These forms are very peculiar and excellent to have if you get them in pre-epic. I'll take a look at each one of them, without being too "numbery", but more in general terms of the characteristics of each shape. At level 20 these become slightly better as you take the form of elder elementals, but the difference is not much. All elemental shapes have immunity to critical hits, disease, mind-affecting spells, paralysis, poison, and sneak attack.

1- Fire Elemental: This is IMO the most useless shape of all the four. It has lowish STR and DEX and a high CON score, which gives you more HP, but lowish AC. The good thing is that it does 1d6 bonus Fire damage each attack, which can be useful vs some undead and high DR monsters.

2- Earth Elemental: This is the lowest AC shape, because of the low DEX, but is also the one with the highest STR, so the highest AB and damage of all. Can be very useful one on one if you can KD your opponent, but the low AC wll make it not worth the trouble when you get surrounded.

3- Water Elemental: This shape is the most well-rounded of all, having the best AB/AC ratio of them all. The AC is MUCH better than that of the Earth elemental, but the AB is only a couple of points lower. The damage is also OK, lower than the Earth one, but not by much. It
has the Drown ability, but the DC is very low, so it's best to avoid it.

4- Air Elemental: This is the highest AC shape of them all. It's a DEX-based shape, so if you have Weapon Finesse, this may be the best of them all. The damage is lowish, though, as any DEX build. If you fight a Dwarven Defender, for example, you won't be doing any damage with this shape. If the target has Greater Stoneskin, you also won't do any damage whatsoever except on criticals, until the spell expires. Has the Whirlwind ability, which makes all surrounding enemies make a Reflex save or fall prone. I don't like this much either, as the DC is bad and if you knock them down you still can't attack them for long.

These shapes are very good to get you from 16 to late 20s, then the AB becomes much less significant and they become more obsolete. What I suggest you to do when this happens is: to get through to the level when you get Dragon Shape, whatever it is in your build, use the Air Elemental shape to tank (preferably with Expertise) and let your companion do the damage, or use spells. The uses of these shapes in high epics are limited but not totally worthless. You can use the Air Elemental to tank and the Water Elemental and Earth Elemental to kill easy mobs (if there are any), saving up Dragon Shape uses for the bigger and tougher battles. The critical hit immunity can be good against devcritters, but your low AC compared to Dragon Shape means that you will get hit by regular blows more often.

- DRAGON SHAPE:

This is probably the best Epic Feat in the game, or at least one of the top 5. The raw power of a Dragon is truly awesome! You get close to 1000 HP, +20 Dodge AC, 48 unbuffed STR (can easily get up to 60) and +6 Dragon Claws, plus True Seeing and DR of 40/+6, plus immunity to the element of your color and a Dragon Breath of the same element. The different shapes and immunities / breath properties are as follows: Red Dragon: Fire, Green Dragon: Acid, Blue Dragon: Electricity. The Red Dragon also receives +50% of Cold damage, which is a weakness that other Dragons don't have. All else is identical.

Now I will talk about the bugged Character Sheet in NWN, and what it shows wrong, so that you can always know what your correct stats are in Dragon Shape:

1- The character sheet shows Weapon Focus and Epic Weapon Focus (Unarmed) as if they worked, but due to a bug that was never corrected by Bioware, they DO NOT WORK! So don't take them. You can verify this with combat debugging.

2- The character sheet doesn't show ANY size modifiers in ANY situation. In Dragon Shape, this means that your AC is 2 points LOWER than what's shown in your sheet. This also applies to AB, but there is yet another imprecision with Dragon AB, so read below to see about your AB. This is also true for Halflings (+1 AB and AC from size modifier aren't shown).

3- The character sheet doesn't show the +6 Dragon Claws, so your AB in Dragon Shape is actually 4 points HIGHER than what the shit sheet shows (+6 from Dragon Claws, -2 from Huge size modifier).

So in summary, your AB/AC in Dragon Shape are +4/-2 from what the Character Sheet shows and WF / EWF don't work. Improved Critical (Unarmed) and Epic Prowess work as they should. If you want to do mental calculations of your AB in Dragon Shape, it's quite easy too. Take your BAB, add your Strength modifier (+25 with 60 STR), +4 from the Claws - Modifier, and +1 from Epic Prowess. That is your AB. An example: 25 BAB (if you go straight Druid) + 25 STR +4 +1 = 55 AB.

HOW TO PLAY DRUIDS:

Firstly, you should never put any points into your physical stats if you don't go for Shifter levels, unless you have them to spare or you need them to attain a certain requirement. You should nearly always start with 18 Wisdom and all your stat increases should be to Wisdom.

- Levels 1-6: At this stage you're UTTERLY WORTHLESS. Without summons you simply can't survive. Thankfully, not only do you have summons, but the best ones too. You can use Animal Empathy to charm an animal, which added with a summoned creature and your companion, will make a little army for you to command. Stay away and just heal them and buff your companion, attacking with a sling if you want to annoy your enemies. Before you get Wildshape, no meleeing for you! Don't use Grease or Entangle because they will cause the animal dominated with animal empathy to turn hostile, as these spells affect allies too.

- Levels 6-15: This is where you start to become better. Your Wildshape will allow you to have very good meleeing, but if you don't have any Monk levels, your AC will be low, so you should rely on casting and summoning mostly, unless you can KD and kill your opponents without getting attacked much. This is when you start to get nice buffs like Awaken and Greater Magic Fang for your companion, and Owl's Insight, Greater Stoneskin, Freedom, Death Ward for you, not to mention capping Barkskin at level 13. Still, rely on summons to do the damage and cast or snipe from afar. Animal Empathy is still useful to provide a meat shield and something to attack. It's better if your server has several levels of critters of the animal subtype.

- Levels 16-30: After you get Elemental shape, your meleeing gains a good boost, mainly because of the much higher ACs of your shapes now. The Bear in Wildshape has a good AB, better even than some of your elementals, but the AC is just much lower. A bear will have about the same AC as an Earth Elemental, which is the lowest AC of them all, but -3 or -4 AB (I think it's -3, but I could be wrong). This stage is also when you get some good offensive spells (you already have the slots, but they're used for buffs). With the extra slots you'll get, your casting will receive a great boost. Now your summons are mostly sidekicks, but your companion is still a good source of damage, just make sure you leave him behind and attract all targets to you, then have him come from behind and wipe everything out. Summon elementals and cast Freedom on yourself and your companion, then paralyze everything with one well-placed Stonehold or Storm of Vengeance spell. You don't need many copies, as the DCs should be VERY HIGH. If you REALLY want to make sure, use two copies of either spell or one of each. Fight Undead with Mass Heal and Sunburst and use Fire Elemental shape to kill them faster, as many undead have fire damage vulnerability. Your AB becomes less attractive closing to level 30, before you get Dragon Shape, which incidentally means that if you delay it too much, you will have to suffer for many levels. I would have to say that save a few exceptions, let 33 be the latest level to attain Dragon Shape, as the growth in power of your enemies will make it very hard to level with your modest Elemental Shape AB.

- Levels 31-40: This is the closing stage of your build. The fact is that after attaining Dragon Shape, you will be pretty close to full power, save very few exceptions. Your AB will be good enough up to level 37 or so, then you'll probably be locked in a few battles of 20s, as the enemies should have high enough ACs to cause you problems, around 70 or so. It's really hard to say this, because all is environment-dependant, but still, everywhere I played so far has been invariably the same dynamic.

A few other pointers that can help you out and are most of the time overlooked by Druid players: Use the following items (in the following order) before shifting to enhance even more your combat prowess: Cat's Grace Potion, Dust of Disappearance, Potion of Aid, Potion of Bless. It may not seem like much of a difference, but if you don't get dispelled, you'll have +2 to AB, +1 or +2 to AC and 50% concealment out of these very simple items. Give preference to a Ioun Stone that gives you DEX, as you have other means to cap Strength. With that Ioun Stone active, you'll have another point of AC. So save them up and use them in tough battles to shift the momentum in your favor.

Last, I'd have to say that the lower the magic setting, the more powerful an unaltered Druid with Dragon Shape will be. That's because of the partial merging of items in shifting and the bonuses given to them in their shapes. The more gimped all other items are, the stronger these bonuses will be in comparison. Inversely, the more powerful the items are, the bonuses will be weaker, and the bonuses lost by items that don't merge will be more significant.

Well, I guess that's about it. At least I cannot think of anything else right now. If I do, I'll add it later. Hope you like and enjoy it.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
Prospective shapechangers may find it useful to know that the attack of all unarmed shapes benefit from the DR buffs i.e. Stoneskin, Gtr Stoneskin, Premonition. Although it does not increase the AB of the claws/bite as a typical weapon enhancement would, it cuts through the DR of foes by the penetration value (not the soak).

So, for example, a druid's dire bear polymorph buffed with Stoneskin would be able to penetrate X/+5 DR of any foe until the spell effects expire by either the duration or collapse. In the same respect, a druid (sorc or wiz) multiclass with access to Epic Warding would be able to cut through DR of X/+20. Also, epic spells can be cast while in the polymorphed form.

This dynamic pretty much contradicts Max's claim that elemental polymorphs cannot cut through DR like a DwD would have. Not innately, but with the appropriate buff, they can.

As for Dragon Shape (as Max has already intimated)...

As uber as it is in low- to mid-magic environments, it pales offensively when weapon enhancements (and item enhancements, in general) become excessive (especially the insane OnHit props on some servers) because the equipment merge is significantly limited compared to armed forms and limited to a +6 enhancement. Also, while in polymorph state, casting from items is impossible, a situation which gives a huge advantage to all non-polymorphed toons.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Vecho wrote:
One downside of animal companions and summon creature is that a animal companions or summon creature counts as a henchman, which will increase your CR and reduces your XP gained. We are talking about 30%-50% XP loss here, which is no insignificant, IIRC.

 
Be careful trying to estimate XP loss due to increased party size, Vecho.  When the target CR is very low, the difference will not represent accurately what the percentage loss is.  Typically (and it depends a lot on how the XP rewards have been scripted), the loss is somewhere around 12-15% per party member.  But the level (HD) of the extra party members has a big impact as well, not only in figuring XP rewards but how encounters are triggered.

As an example, suppose that your solo toon kills a creature for 4 XP.  The same action with companion summoned nets 3 XP.  Add an additional summon for the same encounter and the reward will be 2 XP.  50% XP loss?  Not exactly.  But here is what is happening...

The 12% penalty is applied to 4 XP.  Which brings it down to 3.52 the result which always is rounded DOWN, hence 3.  Now the next penalty is applied to the 3 XP (not combined and applied together against the 4 XP as some might expect).  That brings it down to 2.64, rounded down to 2. 

What this means is that the penalty isn't as significant vs. higher CR kills since the rounding down has less effect (the effect of fractions will be absorbed for the most part) and more accurately approaches the 12% per unit.  But yes, if you are using your support help to kill a mob of goblins, the relative loss will appear to be very high.
So, if you can find a henchman better than animal or summon creature, which is quite common in Single Player Module, it is better to buff your henchman and ignore the animal companions and summon.
 
That's true but perhaps you don't want to risk losing your henchman permanently.  In some modules/environs, once a hench is dead, it's final.  Summons are expendable.  In others venues, the cost to resurrect them is prohibitive on your purse strings.  Still others will charge you an XP penalty to have them rejoin your party. The Biocampaigns were uncharacteristically-liberal by furnishing what amounts to god-like henchmen that can always be recalled free of charge or penalty. 

There's a stategy I always use when using a summon (using more than one, this works but it VERY hard to time just right): 

Let's assume you summon help for an extremely tough boss and you want the full Monty of experience from killing it.  Buff and send in your summon, using any ranged attack (weapon or spells) while your summon has the boss tied up.  As you watch the health of the boss, once it reaches Near Death... unsummon your companion and resume your normal attack (melee, range or spells) to finish it off.  Usually the summon will die before the boss has been injured so fatally but the method I just descibed always assures full XP.  With henchman you need to use a convo to dismiss them and in the heat of battle it is near impossible to do.

One thing Max never mentioned about the animal companions is their one major drawback: They can ALL be feared... easily and often!

They are weak-willed by nature and are worthless vs. mummies and any other NPC that has a fear aura or can cast any will-based spell on them.  Druids do not have Protection vs. Evil in the spellbook so there is no druid buff to protect them. And vs. dragon fear is even worse.  My clerics all immediately switch to Undead summon as soon as they are available.  Druids are stuck with animals for most of pre-epic unfortunately so, as powerful as they might seem, they serve little purpose when they are running in the opposite direction other than acting as an XP drain.  Once a druid reaches level 13, elemental summons are available so mind effects are no longer a concern and the intrinsic basic weakness of the animal companions permanently in the rearview mirror.

Also, Druid spells are pretty much useless before level 7, and their best spells start showing up at 6th spell level, another incentive to go Druid-heavy pre-flop. So by the time you get your Shifter levels up to par, you haven't really used any of the shapes, because they were too low level for the enemies you were facing.

So, let's protest!

WHO WILL WRITE THIS GUIDE? I want to learn too!

Take it EZ!
